text: Thank You Julia for that gracious
introduction
good afternoon members of the HBS
community parents family friends and
most importantly the Harvard Business
School class of 2016
Thank You Marcel II for your inspiring
gift to all of us
Pedro's spirit lives on through you
through you through this class today I'd
like to share with you two personal life
stories that frame what I call the
question my hope is to prompt reflection
and perhaps in in some modest way be
helpful to a few of you in preparing my
remarks I had an opportunity to review a
number of your resumes you are an
amazingly talented and accomplished
group I could learn so much from all of
you but your resumes are incomplete all
resumes are like that they have an
inherently up into the right
characteristic a constant piling on of
ever more impressive accomplishments
accomplishments like graduating from
Harvard Business School a well-crafted
resume can make individual achievements
look so flawless so linear so inexorable
maybe that's actually been true for some
of you but I kind of doubt it all
resumes have a back side if you will and
that back side is the real you all in
your dreams your struggles your love
your fears your failures your
shortcomings anxieties the health of
your relationships with your spouse
family friends with one another your
spiritual and physical self the front of
your resume is the dressed up public you
customized for employers the back side
is the private you
the comprehensive view the often hidden
and occasionally ignored you my own
resume for example fails to mention that
my dad worked in a manufacturing plant
and then when I graduated from UC Davis
my first full-time job was as a bus
driver this was after I opted not to
pursue an enticing opportunity in the
Kmart management training program my
resume does note my time as a field
engineer in Arzu Algeria but it does not
describe my incredible anxiety about
being utterly unqualified for the job
the fact is I dropped out of my
engineering major at UC Davis and my
prior international experience had been
for hours in Tijuana Mexico with my
family my resume proudly proclaims that
I graduated from HBS in 1980 it most
certainly omits
my deep concern my feeling of inadequacy
that I might possibly fail at HBS
especially stressful because I was using
my entire life savings to pay for this
education to this day I am convinced
that the only reason I was accepted by
admissions is they thought I was
Algerian
and it turns out resumes applications
from North Africa were down that year
now the front side of my resume also
disregards a profound truth that HBS
experience opened my young eyes to a
world of possibilities which I could not
previously have imagined HBS gave me
confidence that maybe just maybe I could
do a little bit something special with
my one and only life which brings me to
my two stories both of which are from
the back side of my resume and involve
intense personal struggles my first
story is about a dumb decision involves
Bain & Company line D joy Bain in 1980
out of business school with the
intention of staying for two years just
two years I saw Bain is a sort of
finishing school where I would work hard
learn a lot build my resume I love the
people the entrepreneurial culture the
meritocracy the pragmatic focus on
results they probably had a hundred
employees at the time
it was so intensely private that we were
forbidden to discuss our clients with
anyone including family members fortune
magazine referred to vein as the KGB of
consulting and too hot to handle both of
which we took as compliments a decade
later a decade later I was still at Bain
and still planning to leave within two
years I was energized rather in
bumptious young partner managing Bain
San Francisco office truly enjoying
myself from my space on the 34th floor
of Embarcadero Center I could look
across the bay and actually could see
the Colgate Palmolive
Factory where my dad worked his entire
career apparently I'd arrived but things
were not as they seemed
in reality Bain was facing a devastating
crisis that would turn my little world
upside down these problems were largely
self inflicted a debt Laden financial
structure highly controlled
decision-making inadequate succession
planning had culminated in a downward
spiral
there had been painful layoffs a
restructuring cost-cutting banks fellows
along until Mitt Romney courageously
left his role leading Bain Capital our
sister company and stepped in to
restructure the firm by 1991 the
financial engineering was largely
complete and a new partnership was
formed yet the downward momentum
persisted and the remaining debt
claimants loomed large very large in the
years ahead the entire crisis had caught
me flat-footed and unprepared like being
blindsided in an intersection by a drunk
driver I felt confused I felt trapped do
i forge ahead or accelerate my exit plan
I loved the company and had deep
commitment to my colleagues my
leadership ideals encouraged me as
soldier on on the other hand I'd never
imagined being a career consultant and I
certainly didn't want to spend years of
my life trying to help resuscitate what
looked like a dying business we had a
young son another on the way
a mortgage bills to pay and my career
aspirations extended beyond Bain beyond
consulting I dreamed of being a dynamic
corporate chief executive maybe starting
a company out in Silicon Valley more
resume-building
I finally concluded that I simply could
not in good faith leave my post during a
time of crisis
but when Bain stabilized as soon as I
could look myself in the mirror and say
I've done my duty to the best of my
abilities I would exit to pursue other
opportunities the moment the time was
right I was gonna move on and then in
another entirely unexpected and shocking
turn of events I was asked to run the
firm to re-up big time to take over MIT
as he transitioned back to Bain Capital
this was one future scenario I had not
anticipated I was 38 years old
what should I do what should I do
the smart answer from a rational point
of view seemed inescapable I should
respectfully decline I did not want to
uproot my family to leave my beloved
California and move to Boston leave my
parents my extended family my childhood
home my lifelong friends I had no
intention of remaining in the consulting
industry I had zero turnaround
experience I'd never run anything beyond
a single Bain office and many of my
partners were understandably and loudly
critical of my qualifications if
financial trends continued Bain was
almost certainly in a death spiral
talent leaving clients defecting new
business drying up cost-cutting
cost-cutting a highly respected
investment banker told us that he
believed the firm had less than a 5%
chance of surviving 5%
so much for my up and to the right
career if faint clapped on my watch I
would be held accountable for a historic
headline-grabbing failure I could
visualize the quotes quote Tierney tried
really hard but at the end of the day he
just wasn't the right person for the job
it made no sense absolutely no sense for
me to double down on Bain & Company but
ultimately I made the dumb decision I
said yes to this day I'm not sure why
was it the challenge was it my ego was
it naive confidence was it a sense of
duty
it was certainly instinct over-under
overriding logic in any case I became
president of a name and subsequently
Managing Partner my family did relocate
from California to Boston and I put my
shoulder to the wheel and then things
got worse revenue to continue to decline
turnover accelerated cash flow dwindled
to very very dangerous levels
it was hard and through that turmoil a
single image kept me grounded and
motivated I imagined a day in the future
sitting down with my two sons having to
explain that yes your dad ran a company
called Bain and company doesn't exist
anymore no way no way dumb decision or
not I promised myself I would not give
up now business stories often have
unhappy endings but in this case the new
Bain partnership rallied and after a few
years our turnaround became turbocharged
am i her business miracle and a
testament to the strength of Bane's core
culture and capabilities being once
again became a fast growth prosperous
high-impact firm and a fabulous place to
work today two decades later the firm is
dramatically stronger because of that
crucible now although I'll never know
the path not taken it seems my dumb
decision turned out okay mostly because
I was surrounded by amazingly talented
people when I stepped down in 2000 the
debt was paid off my successor was well
positioned to succeed what did I learn
from this struggle how did it add to the
backside of my resume first of all the
biggest events of life are often
unpredictable and uncontrollable the
best you can do is keep a clear mind and
a steady hand try to do the right thing
whatever that means for you despite the
odds secondly and this was a tough one
for me it's not about me it's natural
for ambitious and competitive people who
want to succeed to view big decisions as
vehicles for their own objectives for
their resumes so to speak
yet struggling with the decision to
double down on invade ultimately led me
to understand that my job was not to
help me it was to truly help other
people our partnership to succeed
I could bring strength and fierce
resolve to every interaction but my
purpose my purpose was to pursue serve
in pursuit of meaningful goals team
goals organizational goals ambitions
that extended beyond my personal
horizons it's not about me it's a third
lesson it is far more important to build
a life than a resume we are defined not
just by our accomplishments but by our
commitments over time our commitments
both professional and personal become
our life's purpose my commitment to
leave Bain was ultimately a decision
about the kind of life I wanted to leave
the kind of person I wanted to breathe
be which brings me to my second story
and another dumb decision for as long as
I can remember I've had a desire to make
a difference in the world as much as I
loved business and love bein I felt
pulled toward public service an interest
which manifested itself early on in my
vain years through a range of pro bono
projects and volunteering and serving on
nonprofit boards I learned a lot about
the social sector and how to be helpful
I even imagined myself launching a make
a difference company although I had no
earthly idea what that might be the
phrase social entrepreneur had not yet
been invented even during the most
intense the most brutal periods of the
Bane turnaround I could not shake my
attraction of the social sector
after a few years the firm's resumed
growth and profitability I began
analyzing social sector trends and
brainstorming possibilities my thought
partner and ultimate co-founder was Jeff
Braddock banal um for my San Francisco
days an associate professor here at HBS
we had no clear goals but we shared a
passion for social impact in the
nonprofit space our quiet little
collaboration ultimately gave birth to
the business plan for the Bridgespan
group in late 1999 my vague notion of
this make a difference company became a
reality pains worldwide organization
received 2 communications both surprises
one message described the launch of
Bridgespan
the other set I was stepping down after
8 years as chief executive after deep
deep personal reflection I finally
decided to say goodbye to my 2,200 Bain
colleagues my leadership role prestige
the compensation to say goodbye to that
to help start a 4-person unproven
nonprofit organization to do so as
non-executive chairman working full-time
earning $1 a year I was 45 years old in
my prime none of this was rational
especially after all the pain of
rebuilding Bain my career repotting was
an unnatural act but to me it may it
just made all the sense in the world
grammar aside I could not not do this it
was about building the life I wanted not
about building my resume rich van was
designed to help nonprofit organizations
and philanthropists achieve breakthrough
results while at the same time
developing ideas of applied knowledge
that could be useful broadly across the
social sector bridge spans combination
consulting firm research institution
teaching vehicle a nonprofit itself
bridge spans serves leaders ng
causes that would not typically have
access to premium professional services
customized to their needs pursues impact
not profit Bridgespan was incubated at
bain and then and then spun out much
like we did with bain capital 15 years
previously it made so much sense to me
but most people thought i should have my
head examined many of my colleagues
referred to my retirement as if i would
be pursuing some sort of hobby like golf
or fly-fishing to vein Partners close
friends privately came into my office
shut the door and asked me if my health
was okay why it's what I quit it was the
height of the dot-com boom and I
actually had a headhunter call me an
idiot he might have been actually called
me a stupid idiot because I could not I
wouldn't consider moving back to
California to run an Internet company
which by the way later crashed a wealthy
private equity investor asked me how
much equity I was getting in bridge span
when I explained him that nonprofits
don't actually have equity he walked
away perplexed seasoned executives told
me earn money now save the do good stuff
for later I was destroying my resume
what a dumb move this intense negative
blowback rattled me really rattled me it
stopped me in my tracks
perhaps I should pursue another big job
earn big money put my social sector
plans on hold perhaps this time I really
was making a dumb decision my heart
overriding my brain thank goodness
thank goodness my family came to my
rescue my wife cares all right 32 years
this year George me said follow your
dreams follow your passion live the life
you were meant to live everything's
gonna work out you'll be a better father
for our wonderful sons Colin and Braden
matter a million times more to me than
my career my loving family kept me
grounded clear minded a cadre of
exceptionally wise individuals beginning
with John Gardner counseled me that at
the end of one's days nothing nothing
matters more than family friends and
whatever little bit you've been able to
do to make the world a better place
social sector leaders including bridge
spans caring donors embraced me all
these people gave me courage Churchill
famously said that fear is a reaction
courage is a decision I decided to dive
in all in I've never looked back fast
forward to today the luckiest guy in the
world I'm able to collaborate with
incredible social sector leaders
outstanding philanthropists amazing
colleagues all with the ambition to help
make our world a better place
what a gift what a blessing what did I
learn from the second struggle once
again life is unpredictable life is
uncontrollable real success is not about
me it's far more rewarding to build a
life than a resume life is much grander
much more significant resumes capture
what we are paid to do but by far the
most essential and fulfilling dimensions
of our life do not come with a paycheck
I now deeply appreciate the personal
fulfillment the energizing passion the
soulful satisfaction serving others of
dedicating oneself to meaningful causes
matter what sector or situation all of
us are different we encounter different
challenges different opportunities along
our life's journey we're conditioned to
pursue this up and to the right path to
build a resume organizations develop us
to be on track on track to the next
promotion on track the next great
assignment on track to the big bonus but
whose track are we on really is it our
track or someone else's track do we like
where the track is leading us do we even
know where the track is leading us which
brings me to my final remarks and the
question Einstein asserted that
questions are more important than
answers when I was younger especially
being a strategy consultant I
concentrated heavily on the answers now
I spend most of my time on the questions
so I have that question for you I call
it that question because it's so
all-encompassing
it's the one we cannot ignore not for
long
cannot escape it's a question that
sooner or later defines us here it is
what is success in life what is success
in your life both sides of your resume
all in not just narrowly defined success
based on what you are paid to do what
about success in marriage success with
family success in friendships
contributions to society what you give
back your humanity your physical and
spiritual and emotional health success
has no formula but if you ignore the
question or push it off until tomorrow
if you fall victim to inertia to others
expectations to the endless pursuit of
more to open to the right at all cost
you will underperform your destiny you
may look great on paper but you won't
look great
in life as you confront the question
you'll struggle with impossible
trade-offs complicated decisions but you
will inevitably make thoughtful choices
intentional choices about what you do
and don't do about how you spend your
precious time the compounding effect of
those choices over time will become your
special one-of-a-kind life today
assembled here together these life
adventures and a range of unforeseen
decisions await all of you just over the
horizon how incredibly exciting how
wonderful
HBS is a phenomenal launching pad in
fact I know exactly exactly
what I was thinking when I was sitting
on that launching pad some 36 years ago
I know that because since my time in
Algeria I've kept a journal it's now
probably 2,500 maybe 3,000 pages long
the stories I've shared with you here
today are not just spotty memories they
reflect countless journal entries
spanning my fears struggles at Bain and
company to my dream of a quote make a
difference company one observation I'd
make looking through those pages all
kinds of things could have turned out
differently I've been very lucky but you
know what's even more amazing during all
these decades I pretty much been myself
it turns out I am Who I am and as long
as I stayed true to who I am as long as
I tried to live my life my way things
seemed to more or less work out the same
will be true for you reminds me of that
Oscar Wilde quote be yourself everybody
else is taken
let me conclude with a brief Tom Tierney
journal entry age 26 a few weeks before
graduating from HBS quote Harvard is
transforming me into a fast track type I
retained my identity and my grassroots
values but I can see that this education
and my talent for leadership will
catapult me to new horizons HBS has
opened my eyes to my own potential
thereby magnifying my ambitions
I now realize that to accomplish any
sort of meaningful social change
I must embark upon the fast-track path
but I must be careful to remain grounded
in my beliefs of equality and social
justice you are an extraordinary class a
community of extraordinary individuals
with more potential in life than you may
fully imagine MH if you succeed in your
own special life keeping your eye on
both sides of your resume and being true
to who you really are
thank you very much
